description: Borrowed from Scots bauther, bather (“to bother”). Origin unknown. Perhaps related to Scots pother (“to make a stir or commotion, bustle”), also of unknown origin. Compare English pother (“to poke, prod”), variant of potter (“to poke”). More at potter. Perhaps related to Irish bodhaire (“noise”), Irish bodhraim (“to deafen, annoy”).

examples: There was a bit of bother at the hairdresser's when they couldn't find my appointment in the book.
Yes, I can do that for you - it's no bother.

verbs.description: bother (third-person singular simple present bothers, present participle bothering, simple past and past participle bothered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To annoy, to disturb, to irritate.
examples: Synonyms: annoy, disturb, irritate, put out, vex; see also Thesaurus:annoy
Would it bother you if I smoked?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To feel care or anxiety; to make or take trouble; to be troublesome.
examples: Synonyms: care, mind; see also Thesaurus:care
Why do I even bother to try?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To do something which is of negligible inconvenience.
examples: You didn’t even bother to close the door.
